title: 108_hr1527
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003" and authorizes appropriations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003 amends Section 1118 of title 49, United States Code, to allocate specific sums for fiscal years 2003-2006 and authorize appropriations for the NTSB Academy. Additionally, it authorizes necessary funds to maintain the Emergency Fund at a level not exceeding $6,000,000. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003 allocates funds for the NTSB Academy for fiscal years 2003-2006, with amounts increasing each year. The total amounts authorized are $3,347,000 for 2003, $4,896,000 for 2004, $4,995,000 for 2005, and $5,200,000 for 2006, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 3. ACCIDENT AND SAFETY DATA CLASSIFICATION AND PUBLICATION. Amends Section 1119 of title 49, United States Code to include procedures for appealing determinations of aircraft accidents. Appeals can be made to the Board, with limitations on applicability in cases resulting in loss of life. SEC. 4. SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION'S RESPONSES TO SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS. Section 1135(d) of title 49, United States Code is amended to require the Secretary to submit annual reports to Congress and the Board on the regulatory status of safety recommendations until final action is taken or determined unnecessary. The Board will notify Congress if the Secretary fails to submit the required annual safety report by March 1. Significant safety recommendations include those on the Board's 'most wanted list' and those related to 15-passenger van safety, railroad grade crossing safety, and medical certifications for commercial driver's licenses. This subsection will end after the report due on February 1. After the report required to be filed on February 1, 2008, is filed. SEC. 5. ASSISTANCE TO FAMILIES OF PASSENGERS INVOLVED IN AIRCRAFT ACCIDENTS. The amendment to Section 1136 of title 49, United States Code, introduces a provision for relinquishment of investigative priority in aircraft accidents. If the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) relinquishes investigative priority to a federal agency willing and able to assist victims and families, the NTSB will still provide assistance to the agency. The National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Bureau of Investigation will revise their 1977 agreement on accident investigations within a year of this Act's enactment. The revised agreement will consider amendments made to prioritize assisting families in accidents. Section 1131(a)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by moving subparagraphs (B) and (C) 4 ems to the left.
